slide illustrates the problem that we're trying to solve with with coop flow so one of the things that we've learned a
lot at Google having deployed a lot of ML systems in in production so my is his
background my first job at Google was working on the YouTube video recommendation system and so this slide
resonates a lot with me because what we found is that when you're deploying ml systems in production you spend most of
your time not on the actual ml code which is this bit like so we tend to
think of ml we think about the algorithms the deep neural nets and all the complex maps that sort of powers them what we've actually found is that
most of the time and energy that goes into maintaining systems and products is all the supporting services
around them so you know you have to do all of your data ingestion your data cleaning you have to manage resources
for your serving infrastructure your data processing infrastructure you have all the actual serving infrastructure
you have all the monitoring to keep things up and healthy and so what we've
realized is that ml in production requires DevOps and it requires lots of
it and so you know as I think everybody in this conference can probably appreciate containers and kubernetes are
really great at DevOps and so we wanted to try to use containers and kubernetes to solve some of the DevOps challenges
of ml and so the goal with Kubb flow is to build a kubernetes native platform
for ml so that we can make ml portable and what we mean by portable is making it easy to move from local development
on your on your machine into your your staging or test clusters and then finally into production so what exactly
is Kubb flow first and foremost we're a community so we are a growing community of you know data scientists DevOps
engineers software engineers product managers and as a community we're coming
together to build an ml platform and to build that ml platform on top of kubernetes and the reason that we're all coming
together to build a platform is because I think there's a growing recognition that building an ml platform is a really
big problem and it's a lot easier to build it together as an open community and everybody and have everybody
contributed to it rather than trying to build it all by yourself and I think this is a lesson that we're taking from
the kubernetes community where we've seen that you know kubernetes was very successful because they built an open
platform then brought a lot of people into that platform that contributed contributed to it to it I think that's
one of the main reasons why you know kubernetes has been as successful as it is so we're trying to recapture that magic as I said before coop flow wants
to be a kubernetes native platform from machine learning and so what that means a couple of things first and foremost we
we are taking advantage of them we are kuben we run wherever kubernetes runs right we're taking a hard
dependency on kubernetes and that's because we're we're relying on kubernetes to be the
basis of our portability story right so kubernetes runs locally on your machine and your machine using mini cube or now
docker you can also run it in your on-prem clusters you can also run it in the cloud so if you have a platform that
runs on kubernetes then it's easy to move that platform and any products built on those platforms across those
different environments we're also taking advantage of kubernetes functionality
and api's to solve some of the problems that you have in machine learning so a particular example of that is a lot of
your machine learning frameworks today like tensorflow support distributed training which is very important to
scaling out in being able to Train large models on large data sets right and so with tens of with distributed training
you often have to manage multiple processes so in a distributed tensorflow job you have a master process which is
coordinating the training you have workers which are actually doing the the actual work and then you have parameter
servers that basically ask act as a distributed data store for your parameters that you're learning so we've
started building custom resources to to solve that problem and and make it easy to manage all those resources taking
advantage of kubernetes and other companies like Selden have contributed custom resources to handle other
problems like managing model deployments and rollouts we're also following
kubernetes patterns so we you know we view ml as a set of micro services and
we're following that pattern and we're also you know taking a declarative approach to managing you know
infrastructure like kubernetes does and then finally we package all this up together as case' net packages there's a
bunch of seats you know up front and you should feel free to fill in and so you
know at its heart you know what we're providing with coop flow is case net packages that make it easy to deploy all
these micro services in a way that makes them easy to manage together and finally
we want to provide end-to-end machine learning solutions that are built on coop flow and illustrate how you can

we're a community so we have about 70 individual members and we have over 20-plus organizations

you're if you're building ml solutions these are all the services you kind of
need at a high level right so at a to start you need services to do data ingestion data analysis data
transformation you then need to do actually train models using a framework
like tensorflow or py torch you then want to be able to scale that out so that you can actually train at scale
then you finally need to roll that out into production and serve those model models and then once you're serving
those models you actually need to monitor it and make it operational right so our goal with with coop flow is
really to fill in all these existing boxes and provide a cohesive solution for using all these boxes together
and so then this is what the the user experience looks like if you're actually trying to develop you know ml solutions

types of components within coop flow so there's there's first and foremost those are the components being developed

developed by you know the core contributors of coop flow but then a lot of our components are actually existing

PAP platform and so these components are not maintained within coop flow they're
maintained outside and so they're not subject to coop flows governance so you
can if you so choose you can have maintained header control of your component but still have that component

our py torch operator which will probably make it into our next release we also have a cafe to operator that's

bod which is a add-on to tensorflow that allows you to run distributed tensorflow using MPI and
it's a way to do distribute training the Intel folks have contributed KBC which
is a kubernetes volume controller and what this does is it basically moves data back and forth from say your object
store to your nodes and cassia's it on your nodes and the idea there is to move manage data in a way
that's that serves ml workloads efficiently then we have cat tib cat tib
is a hyper parameter tuning system it's a clone of visi a Google's HP tuning
system the clone was not developed by Google it was developed by some people some contributors who have contributed
to cupola and then you know finally we're sort of closing some of the gaps
around using existing systems so as an example we're providing docker images for TF serving which is a model server

bunch of lists of the different projects that we've already started integrating into coop flow but are developed outside

get more data so you can imagine if you're generating recommendations for a web site like YouTube you have a you

CF or possibly some other foundation so we're we're targeting a 0.2 release
at the end of this quarter and we sort of hope to get into a release cadence of having a release every every quarter so

tab for HP tuning py torch for training py to py torch models we'd like to have
batch inference horribad integration we're adding a central UI to to make it

our existing components including a new API or a new version of the API for our
TF job operator so with that I'd like to
switch and switch gears a little bit and try to talk about some of you know what I think are some core principles for
coop flow and so let's I think there's about three of them so the first one is
you know we want to be open and I've already sort of talked about why we want to be be open it's because it's such a
big problem that we're we're trying to tackle we think being open is going to be critical to our success and we also
think that this is an important lesson to be learned from the kubernetes community what this means is from the
beginning of coop flow we've spent a fair bit of time trying to ensure that everybody within the community so not
just Google who sort of you know kicks things off has an equal opportunity to take on leadership roles and other roles
in the community so from a from religious logistical perspective we've
tried to give equal access to like our test infrastructure our release infrastructure - you know external
external external contributors so not just Google so there's really no
difference between Google contributors and non Google contributors it also means that our success will depend on
everyone carrying water and chopping wood and so I think as we grow this is one of the big challenges that we face
as a community so as an example the the number of PRS per week is roughly about
two times the number of commits right now so we're we're not sort of keeping up with
with our velocity so it's important for us to get more people to act as
reviewers from the community so that we can we don't restrain our velocity by our review capacity the second principle
that we have is we want to have a low bar and a high ceiling so a low bar means we want to make it super easy to
get started with coop flow and so one of the challenges there is we need to
minimize the number of kubernetes concepts and api's that users need to learn to get started you know there's a
lot of data scientists and m/l researchers that would like to use coop flow and start to get some of the advantages of kubernetes but trying to
get up to speed on kubernetes is can really be trying to drink from a fire hose so you know trying to make that as
simple as possible make it as easy to deploy coop flow without knowing too much about kubernetes is a high priority
for us and this is a very active area in the community in terms of trying to figure out how to make the API is more
friendly and amenable to data scientists but by a high ceiling though we want to
make it very easy for you know system administrators and people that are knowledgeable of kubernetes to take full
advantage of kubernetes to do complex customizations and so that's everything from you know configuring complex
security policies or volume management and we so we yeah and then one of the
reasons we want to do that is because we've seen from kubernetes we think that extensibility has been key to kubernetes
success so we want to make sure that coop flow is very extensible and can be easily adapted to different use cases
and not sort of limit what people can do with it and finally we want to be you
know kubernetes native and so you know as I said every earlier we want to run
anywhere kubernetes runs and we want to reuse kubernetes concepts and api is like custom resources are a perfect

mech mechanisms so you know using the API server as for opportunist

before you know kubernetes has a very steep learning curve and so if you're going to expose those kubernetes
concepts and api's like we do in the TF job operator with the pod template spec that arguably creates
a barrier to to data scientists which
you know sort of goes against our idea of being low bar and so trying to figure out how to reconcile those two two

one of the things that we'd like to avoid is having users fall off the cliff and so what I mean by this is you know
